section.title: Product-Specific Forms
section.para: As was stated in the section Existing Records, the form displayed by all the sub-menu items of Existing Records has a link at the bottom called Edit Transaction Details, which when clicked displays extra sections of the form. These sections contain fields specific to the product (LC, EL, IR, and so on), and you can use them to update details of the original transaction. Product Specific Forms
This section describes these sections, for each product.

In addition, the forms displayed by the six "notification" actions have several sections that are the same in all six, plus a final part that is specific to the product. . In each case this final part is the same as the extra part of the Existing Records form for that product. However, it is permanently present (no Edit Transaction Details link), because these actions create the initial transaction.

section.title: Import Letter of Credit Form
section.para:
A Letter of Credit (LC) or Documentary Credit is a banking mechanism that enables importers to offer secure terms to exporters. It is an undertaking given by a bank (the Issuing Bank) on behalf of the buyer (applicant) to pay a seller (beneficiary) a given amount of money on presentation of specified documents guaranteeing the supply of goods within specific time limits. These documents, conforming to terms and conditions set out in the letter of credit, are to be presented at a specified place. Forms
Import Letter of Credit
Import Letter of Credit Form
Product Specific Forms
Product Specific Forms
Import Letter of Credit Form

The form described in this section deals with the business details of an LC for which your bank is the Issuing Bank. It can be activated through the Edit Transaction Details feature found in the reporting page of the Pending and Existing Records when the product record edited is such an Import LC.
This large input form preloaded with the current master details of the transaction is split in various sections.

section.title: Issued Standby Letter of Credit Form
section.para:
Even though it is based on a flow of documents related to a business transaction between a buyer and seller, the Standby Letter of Credit is not directly related to the movement of goods. Forms
Issued Standby Letter of Credit
Issued Standby Letter of Credit Form
Product Specific Forms
Product Specific Forms
Issued Standby Letter of Credit Form

It acts more like a guarantee. It means the beneficiary will receive a payment from the Issuing Bank in the event of default on a contract, provided that the complying documents (usually a sight draft) are presented.
A Standby Letter of Credit can be governed by either the UCP 500 rules or the more specific ISP 98 practices.

For business transactions that require regular exchanges between a buyer and a seller, a Standby Letter of Credit can include an Evergreen clause. This means the guarantee is automatically regularly renewed and so does not have an expiry date.

The Issued Standby LC focuses on the applicant side and is therefore very similar to the Import Letter of Credit seen previously. The key difference is that it can also be issued through a fairly unstructured form providing a large text area for the client to enter the details of the requested Standby LC.

When the bank edits a reporting message on this product, the form automatically inherits from the one used for its original issuance: if the Standby LC was initiated through a standard form, the same form as for an Import LC is displayed; if it was issued as a set of free format terms, the related form is loaded.
The following focuses on that free format option. For further details on the structured form, see the Import Letter of Credit section.

section.title: Shipping Guarantee Form
section.para:
A Shipping Guarantee (SG) is an undertaking by a bank to the shipping owner or agent of a vessel, to release goods to the importer pending receipt of the original Bill of Lading. This helps the importer to clear the purchased goods under a Letter of Credit or a simple documentary collection while waiting for shipping documents to be presented. Hence it can for instance save the client from storage charges levied by the port authorities due to late arrival of the shipping documents or delays in clearance of the goods. Some Letters of Indemnity could also be handled through this module. Forms

A Financing Request or Trade Financing (TF) is a transaction issued in the by the client and sent to a designated bank (the lender, also called Issuing Bank of the loan in the rest of this document) whereby that import or export customer requests some form of financing in the scope of an International Trade transaction. section.para:
Documentary Collection is a method of payment used in international trade, whereby the exporter entrusts the handling of trade documents to banks and gives the banks instructions concerning the release of these documents to the importer. Forms

Export Documentary Collection (often abbreviated to Export Collection) refers to the export side of such transactions where the bank plays the role of the Remitting Bank and where the client is the drawer of the collection.
Two types of Export Collections are handled:

listitem.para: Regular Collections where the remitting bank will be responsible for the sending of the documents to the presenting bank on the import side,
Direct Collections where the drawer himself ships the documents to the presenting bank and only instruct his bank to handle the remaining of the transaction.

section.title: Generating the Cover Letter
section.para: During the initial receipt of the Direct Collection instructions by the Remitting Bank, you can optionally use to generate and submit to your customer the actual cover letter that the customer will use to send directly the documents to the Presenting Bank. This method circumvents a classical flaw of direct collections whereby the Remitting Bank is reluctant to provide its customer with blank forms bearing its letterhead without any control on them.
The built-in flow for the generation and attachment of the cover letter is the following:

listitem.para: The bank receives the request through the middle-office screen and prepares the reporting bearing its approval of the collection instructions.

While performing this task on a direct collection record, you can decide to automatically generate and attach the related cover letter. This is done in Input mode by checking a dedicated check box in the Reporting Message Details section of the screen. At any time, with the icon
, you can call a preview of the letter available as an Acrobat PDF file.

When you click Save / Submit, the server-side logic generates a new attachment and adds it to the list of files attached to the reporting message. This PDF file becomes the original copy that the customer will receive, and subsequently print and attach to the documents sent to the import side.

section.title: Fund Transfer Product
section.para:
In an international trade transaction, a client can use this (FT) module to request a fund transfer, for which the bank (called the Ordering Bank) can subsequently send an acknowledgement upon successful completion. Fund Transfer Product
Product Specific Forms
Product Specific Forms
Fund Transfer Product

The module is a simple Cash Management feature. It enables an applicant company to do two types of transfer: Internal, which the client uses to transfer funds between two accounts both belonging to the client, and Outgoing, which the client uses when an external beneficiary is the recipient of the transfer, possibly with another banking institution acting as an intermediary. An outgoing transfer is also called a third-party transfer.

Unlike the other products in , the module is associated with a single event (the submission of the transfer request and the bank's reply), and therefore has no free format message feature for further interaction between client and bank.

Therefore the bank side of the Fund Transfer product is limited to a review of the instructions sent by the client and the interaction is limited to the common input fields available for every reporting message generated by the bank from a pending customer request. See the chapter detailing this common function for further details.
